results.headline: In the Shadows, With Their Physical and Moral Impairments
results.summary_short: A criminal enforcer ends up working with an assassin’s blind sister in the Italian film “Salvo.”

results.display_title: Expedition to the End of the World
results.headline: Sailing Toward an Arctic Armageddon
results.summary_short: “Expedition to the End of the World” documents an Arctic voyage by Danish scientists who muse on the region’s natural wonders and uncertain future.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Expedition to the End of the World

results.headline: Montana Skies, Childhood Wounds
results.summary_short: “Winter in the Blood,” based on a 1974 James Welch novel, is the story of an alcoholic Blackfoot Indian man in Montana.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Winter in the Blood

results.headline: Un-American, Some Said. But Not Unworthy.
results.summary_short: Thom Andersen and Noël Burch’s film “Red Hollywood” makes a case for the quality of work by blacklisted filmmakers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Hollywood

results.headline: An Aging Beauty With Good Bones
results.summary_short: “Dinosaur 13” looks at the famous find of a T. rex skeleton in South Dakota and the legal case that followed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dinosaur 13

results.headline: Love and Unhappiness, in Soft Shades of Gray
results.summary_short: In Philippe Garrel’s “Jealousy,” emotional ambivalence and wayward passion span years among a group of struggling artists.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La jalousie

results.headline: Cutting Very Close to the Truth
results.summary_short: “Abuse of Weakness,” based on the director Catherine Breillat’s own book, focuses on a woman entranced by a swindler.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Abus de Faiblesse

results.headline: They Want to Rock, but There’s More to Life
results.summary_short: “We Are Mari Pepa” follows the summer of four Mexican teenagers with a rock band, especially the group’s leader, Alex.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Somos Mari Pepa

results.headline: Grieving, With a Score to Settle
results.summary_short: “The Word” centers on a businessman’s reaction to a cult’s ritual killing of his son.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Word

results.headline: On the Road Again, Riffing Over Pasta
results.summary_short: A freewheeling jaunt along the Amalfi Coast, with literary touchstones, starring Rob Brydon and Steve Coogan in a sequel to their 2010 movie, “The Trip.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Trip To Italy

results.headline: If You Want to Remember, You Have to Ask the Old Guy
results.summary_short: Lois Lowry’s novel “The Giver” is adapted for film by the director Phillip Noyce.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Giver

results.headline: Muscles and Testosterone Are Ready for Action
results.summary_short: Sylvester Stallone heads a celebrity cast — Mel Gibson, Antonio Banderas, Wesley Snipes and more — in the explosion-packed film “The Expendables 3.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Expendables 3

results.headline: Inside a 16th-Century Naval Battle
results.summary_short: “The Admiral,” starring Choi Min-sik, depicts a 1597 naval battle in which a Korean David fought a Goliath Japan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Admiral: Roaring Currents

results.display_title: Mr. X: A Vision of Leos Carax
results.headline: Behind the Enigma of a Cult-Favorite Film Auteur
results.summary_short: In “Mr. X: A Vision of Leos Carax,” Tessa Louise-Salomé turns a documentary eye on a French filmmaker.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. X: A Vision of Leos Carax

results.headline: Sins of a Father Visited Upon a Son
results.summary_short: In “Moebius,” the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk tells a silent tale of a maddened mother who slices off her son’s penis in revenge for her husband’s infidelity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moebius

results.headline: His Girlfriend Is Dead (Shh, Don’t Tell Her)
results.summary_short: Jeff Baena’s feature debut, “Life After Beth,” stars Aubrey Plaza as a lusty, undead girlfriend blissfully unaware that she’s past her expiration date.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life After Beth

results.headline: A Badge, a Car, a Vest and Most of the Rest
results.summary_short: “Let’s Be Cops” brings together Damon Wayans Jr. and Jake Johnson as two characters who need a boost, and get one.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let's Be Cops

results.headline: A Midlife Crisis, With Many Selves
results.summary_short: Jake is a filmmaker frustrated with parenthood and lonely after a divorce. What better way to solve this existential crisis than to make a movie about his life?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jake Squared

results.headline: Sexual Encounters and Meta Moments
results.summary_short: Misdirections abound in Julián Hernández’s “I Am Happiness on Earth,” a film of dour, sexually explicit couplings and triplings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Happiness On Earth

results.headline: Music for Its Own Sake, Until a Dreamer Intrudes
results.summary_short: “Frank” centers on a highly eccentric musical group whose equilibrium is disturbed when it is joined by an admiring outsider.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frank
